w:r.w:t: Age Estimation from Voice + Gender Recognition from Fingerprint
1. Project Overview (Say this EXACTLY in interview)
“My major project is a multimodal biometric system that predicts a person’s age from their voice and gender from their fingerprint.
The reason we built two separate models is because multimodal biometrics are far more reliable than single-biometric systems.
I led the entire project end-to-end — data preprocessing, feature extraction, CNN model training, fingerprint feature engineering, evaluation, and integration.”
2. Why Multimodal Instead of Single Biometric?
Single biometrics (only fingerprint or only voice) are unreliable under noise, distortion, or spoofing.
Combining both increases accuracy, robustness, and security.
Removed background noise using band-pass filters
CNN treats it like an image

“I managed the fingerprint pipeline — dataset quality, feature engineering, and model training.”

Say the main intro I gave.
Q6. What challenges did you face?
Q7. How did you improve accuracy?
Q9. What did you learn as team lead?
Multimodal Biometric Age and Gender Prediction System
. It uses two separate pipelines — a
voice-based CNN model for age estimation
fingerprint-based ML model for gender classification
For voice analysis, I extracted MFCCs, chroma, and mel spectrograms from the Mozilla Common Voice dataset and trained a CNN to classify age groups.
For fingerprints, I extracted ridge density, minutiae and texture features and trained an SVM/CNN to classify gender.
I led the team, designed the architecture, handled preprocessing, feature extraction, model training, and final integration.
The final system takes both voice and fingerprint and gives a combined output like ‘Male, 20–29’.
This project gave me deep experience in machine learning, audio processing, computer vision, CNNs, project leadership, and multimodal AI.”
Features: MFCC, Chromagram, Mel Spectrogram, ZCR, Pitch
Features: Ridge Density, LBP, Minutiae, Wavelets
This is EVERYTHING you need for your interview.
